coredata.dc:title: Metallic glasses: Elastically stiff yet flowing at any stress

coredata.dc:creator: Riechers, Birte
Das, Amlan
Rashidi, Reza
Dufresne, Eric
Maaß, Robert
coredata.dc:description: Crystalline solids have a minimum stress needed to displace atoms or to move defects. This stress defines the true elastic limit and is generally a sizeable share of the macroscopic yield stress. Here we demonstrate that a metallic glass, an amorphous solid with a yield stress in the giga-pascal regime, lacks such a true microscopic elastic limit. Leveraging in-situ coherent x-ray scattering, we uncover a strongly accelerated atomic-scale transport upon the application of a stress as small as 0.005 times the yield stress. With increasing stress levels, the distribution of structural relaxation times changes from compressed exponential to simple exponential form, revealing a stress–temperature equivalence in the time-scale domain. These findings strongly promote a microstructurally heterogeneous picture of metallic glasses, in which a part of the amorphous microstructure controls macroscopic yielding whereas another part admits microplastic flow at any stress.

xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: The authors thank P.M. Derlet and Mo Li for fruitful discussions. Financial support by the European Union\u2019s Horizon Europe Framework Programme (HORIZON) under the Marie Sk\u0142odowska Curie grant agreement (No. 101063523) and the Adolf Martens Fond of BAM are gratefully acknowledged.

The authors thank P.M. Derlet and Mo Li for fruitful discussions. Financial support by the European Union's Horizon Europe Framework Programme (HORIZON) under the Marie Sk\u0142odowska Curie grant agreement (No. 101063523), the German Research Foundation, DFG, (Grant No. 466247278), and the Adolf Martens Fond of BAM are gratefully acknowledged. A.D. acknowledges the support of the National Science Foundation (BIO, ENG and MPS Directorates) under award DMR-1829070 and DMR-2342336 as well as the support of the Air Force Research Laboratory under agreement number FA8650-22-2-5200. The XPCS experiments were performed at the X-ray Science Division beamline 8ID-E of the Advanced Photon Source, a U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Science User Facility operated for the DOE Office of Science by Argonne National Laboratory under Contract No. DE-AC02-06CH11357. R.M. designed the study. B.R. and A.D. conducted the experiments. A.D. R.R. and B.R. developed and conducted the analysis. B.R. and R.M. wrote the manuscript. All authors contributed to the interpretation and presentation of the results.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para:
Schematics of the experimental setup and the applied load protocol. The scattered portion of a coherent x-ray beam is measured by a detector in reflection mode after interaction with a compressively stressed sample. In the load protocol, compressive stress is shown as a function of waiting time with yellow bars marking sections during which XPCS measurements were conducted. The time between the alteration of the stress amplitude and the re-initiation of tracking the structural dynamics by XPCS corresponds to the distance between dotted lines and is indicated as
Δ
t
w
.

The effect of stress on the structural dynamics of a metallic glass. TTCFs taken under constant load conditions for increasing stress amplitudes ranging from zero applied load in (a) to 0.8 σy in (f). The time window over which the individual TTCFs were tracked varies and is indicated for each panel.

(a) Quantitative evolution of momentary relaxation time scales, plotted logarithmically as a function of linear waiting time, for compressive stress amplitudes ranging from zero to 0.8 σy. Anchors reflect the lower boundary of momentary time scales,
ξ
lb
, in the decelerated dynamic regime. (b) Average stretching exponent and initial slope of non-zero stress time-scale data from the main panel plotted as functions of logarithmic stress amplitude. (c) Natural logarithm of the normalized momentary relaxation time scales as a function of waiting time (full lines) with a normal exponential function (dotted line) and compressed exponential functions (dashed lines) as guides to the eye.

Recovery from stress-driven alterations in structural dynamics in view of an elastically stiff percolative network. (a) TTCF recorded immediately after unloading from 0.02 σy and (b) TTCF recorded about 80 h after unloading and maintained zero-load. Panel (c) plots the quantitative evolution of momentary relaxation time scales from the TTCF in (b) logarithmically as a function of linear waiting time. The grey bar reflects the lower boundary of the momentary time scales connected to the TTCF in (a). The contrast range in (a) and (b) is identical to Fig. 2. Panel (d) shows a surface mesh enclosing atoms with coordination of icosahedral (0, 12, 0) and Frank-Kasper-type structures, i.e., (0, 12, 2), (0, 12, 3), and (0, 12, 4), derived from molecular dynamics simulation (see Ref. [25] for details), that extends to a percolating network.

head.ce:title: Metallic glasses: Elastically stiff yet flowing at any stress

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Crystalline solids have a minimum stress needed to displace atoms or to move defects. This stress defines the true elastic limit and is generally a sizeable share of the macroscopic yield stress. Here we demonstrate that a metallic glass, an amorphous solid with a yield stress in the giga-pascal regime, lacks such a true microscopic elastic limit. Leveraging in-situ coherent x-ray scattering, we uncover a strongly accelerated atomic-scale transport upon the application of a stress as small as 0.005 times the yield stress. With increasing stress levels, the distribution of structural relaxation times changes from compressed exponential to simple exponential form, revealing a stress–temperature equivalence in the time-scale domain. These findings strongly promote a microstructurally heterogeneous picture of metallic glasses, in which a part of the amorphous microstructure controls macroscopic yielding whereas another part admits microplastic flow at any stress.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: The data is available on https://zenodo.org/. The XPCS data analyzed in this study has been deposited at zenodo.org with the digital object identifier https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14352407.

ce:sections.ce:para: Amorphous solids distinguish themselves from their crystalline counterparts by a broad distribution of nearest neighbor distances, prominently reflected in the full-width-at-half-maximum of the first peak of the structure factor in an x-ray scattering experiment [1,2]. This lack of long-range order has important technological and fundamental implications since the structural disorder is intimately connected to a wide distribution of both barrier energies for structural transitions and of relaxation times [3]. For example, a large fraction of shallow transition barriers is expected to facilitate aging, driving the out-of-equilibrium solid towards a lower energy state that, depending on the time scales, may even be a geometrically frustrated near-to-crystalline structure, as in the here considered case of metallic glasses (MGs).

Motivated by a hierarchy of structural and temporal heterogeneities [4–7], experiments and atomistic simulations have demonstrated a wide range of atomic scale microplastic transitions that a MG can access to explore its potential-energy landscape via athermal [8,9] or thermal fluctuations [10–12]. Deep in the glassy solid regime, the latter type of such structural rearrangements are classified experimentally into the well-known
γ
- and
β
-loss modes [7,13,14], of which
β
-losses may be localized string-like excitations that collectively mediate irreversible transitions into new inherent structures [15,16]. In addition to thermally-driven transport during aging, a (thermo-mechanical) stress bias is, from the general thermal-activation framework, expected to accelerate structural evolution. Indeed, certain stress protocols allow (transient) macroscopic rejuvenation of the solid [17–21]. As such, the ability to assess a vast landscape of shallow barriers offers unique means to not only tune the enthalpy state of a MG, but to also reverse thermally-induced aging and therefore the deterioration of macroscopic properties [22].

In contrast to the barrier-energy perspective and its implication for a rich structural activity even by unbiased thermal activation, stands the robust elastic limit with Weibull moduli as high as for Al- or Fe-based engineering alloys [23]. This remarkable property combination can now be rationalized based on recent atomistic simulations covering the micro-second time-scale regime that upon isothermal aging reveal a strong structural partitioning, resulting in an elastically stiff percolative network of minimally frustrated environments [24,25]. Whilst the exact microstructural evolution into such structurally different domains depends on the details of used inter-atomic potentials and can differ in their topological realization for multi-component bulk metallic glasses, model glasses reveal stable motifs forming a network structure, whereas the remaining more-frustrated substructure admits microplasticity and transport [26]. For example, emerging stable motifs in the case of a Lennard-Jones potential are icosahedrally-coordinated or of Frank-Kasper type, whereas an embedded-atom potential may yield Bernell-type motifs. Irrespective of this, the qualitative outcome of the microstructure remains the same: a network of energetically more stable motifs is formed. With this microstructural picture, the current view on stress-driven structural excitations, such as shear transformations, shear-transformation zones, or free volume transport [27] is extended, as it primarily relates them to the more-frustrated substructure instead of the elastically stiff percolative system-spanning network. In view of these substantially different structural environments that can be uniquely identified via their spatial connectivity of topologically distinct bonding environments [28], the question arises if the microplasticity-admitting substructure of a MG at all has a true elastic limit. If not, enthalpy tuning, rejuvenation and therefore the dialing-in of specific macroscopic properties should be feasible at unexpectedly low stresses and would entail only one true elastic limit – the macroscopic yield stress, set by the elastically stiff percolative network.

To scrutinize the lack of a microscopic elastic limit and the therewith connected microstructural view, we set out to probe the dynamics of structural rearrangements in a Zr-based MG under uniaxial compression using x-ray photon correlation spectroscopy (XPCS), a scattering method exploiting partial coherency that allows probing the time-dependent evolution of structural relaxation times via intensity cross-correlations of x-ray speckle patterns [29,30]. Specifically, XPCS gives access to the momentary structural relaxation times for the chosen scattering vector sampled by the x-ray speckles. This ability to directly assess the intermediate scattering function (ISF) provides completely new atomic-scale insights into structural dynamics and relaxation of MG-forming alloys in the undercooled liquid and solid state. These phenomena include time aging-time superposition [31–33], its violation via mechanical stress [34], intermittent aging [35–37], and wave-vector dependent dynamics in the supercooled liquid [38], all of which occur independently of alloy chemistry, emphasizing the general physics underlying such phenomena.

Here, we will leverage XPCS to capture the stress-driven acceleration of structural dynamics far below yield. Conducted in-situ, the experiments demonstrate distinct stress-induced dynamic responses deviating from the zero-stress scenario. These include the drop of relaxation times by an order of magnitude via the application of stresses as small as 0.005 of the yield stress,
σ
y
, reflecting the easy admittance of stress-driven microplastic transport. We further observe a distinct change in waiting-time dependent dynamics compared to the zero-stress level, where a quicker exhaustion of short decorrelation times occurs with increasing applied stress. This behavior is accompanied by a transition of the relaxation time distribution from a clearly compressed to an exponential form with increasing stress amplitude, suggesting a change in the transport mechanism at the highest pre-yield stresses. Such a cross-over in the shape exponent gives strong evidence for a stress–temperature equivalence since cooling through the glass transition obeys a similar exponential-to-compressed decorrelation transition [39]. Upon unloading after an elastostatic load sequence, transport is initially arrested. Indeed, after unloading decorrelation times largely exceed the XPCS probing time. This indicates how the stressed glass must have attained a deep low-energy configuration in the underlying energy landscape. Measurable decorrelations reemerge after dozens of hours of waiting time, indicate that the observed dynamical arrest is a transient effect. Together, these observations give strong evidence for a glassy solid that can carry GPa-large stresses prior to macroscopic yielding but that at the same time admits microplastic structural transport even at the lowest applied stresses.

Samples were cut by electrical discharge machining from a 1.5 mm thick MG plate of Zr52.5Ti5Cu17.9Ni14.6Al10 (in at.%, Vitreloy 105,
T g
= 675
K [40], σy = 1700 MPa [41], where
T g
is the glass transition temperature) purchased from Liquidmetal® to a size of 1.0 × 1.5 × 4.0 mm3. In-situ XPCS measurements were conducted at the 8-ID-E beamline of the Advanced Photon Source (APS) at Argonne National Laboratory at ambient temperature (
0.44 T
g
) and atmosphere. The samples were probed in reflection mode with a photon beam of 7.32 keV at a scattering angle of

The beam was focused and slit into a probe of 35 µm2, corresponding to a surface coverage of 10 × 10 µm2 on the sample surface in the given scattering geometry. A photon counting Lambda 250 K pixel array detector of 19 × 19 mm2 size with 55 µm pixel size was used to record speckle patterns at a distance of ca. 1 m and with a temporal resolution of 2.5 s. All speckle patterns were masked and normalized along the beamline’s standard analysis routine, presented in detail in the Supplementary Material. Subsequently, the two-time correlation-function (TTCF),

, was calculated for each set of consecutive speckle patterns connected to a given stress amplitude. In-situ mechanical uniaxial loading for static stress application was done using a compact load frame, developed at Cornell University. To probe without applied load, samples were located in the load frame, but only held in place by gravimetric forces, i.e. at zero compressive load. The load-cell voltage was tracked throughout the beamtime to allow for a precise correlation between applied stresses and structural dynamics probed with XPCS. A variety of static loading sequences as a function of waiting time,
t w
, were pursued. A schematic of the loading protocol and the experimental setup are shown in Fig. 1 . As a first step, a jump in stress from the zero-load state (A) at 0 N to a given stress,
σ
A
(B), was applied. Subsequently, an unload to the minimally applicable load of the load-frame of
10 N
(

(C) followed without any interruption in the speckle pattern recording. In selected cases, a final XPCS experiment was conducted after a complete unload to 0 N and a waiting-time delay

of several tens of hours (D).

Following the protocol exemplified in Fig. 1, a selection of TTCFs for different stress levels is shown in Fig. 2 . These TTCFs represent the dynamical behavior for increasing stress levels, as indicated in each sub-panel. At zero load (Fig. 2(a), corresponding to stage A in Fig. 1), a broad diagonal of higher contrast characterizes the TTCF that also exhibits some degree of non-monotonic contrast fluctuations. This indicates heterogeneous structural dynamics, representing thermally-driven structural activity at the probed length scale [25]. Biasing the MG with a stress of
0.005 σ
y
(Fig. 2(b), corresponding to
σ
A
= 0.005 σ
y
during stage B in Fig. 1) changes the TTCF markedly. For the first 10 000 s, dramatically accelerated decorrelation is observed. This narrowing of the diagonal high-contrast regime in comparison to the zero-load state persists over the entire waiting time of 20 000 s and its continuous broadening signifies the gradual increase of relaxation times, that is stress-driven aging. Successively higher
σ
A
levels reveal a similar initially accelerated dynamical response relative to the un-biased state, as demonstrated for
0.01 σ
y
,
0.04 σ
y
,
0.2 σ
y
,
and
0.8 σ
y
,
and displayed in Fig. 2(c), 2(d), 2(e), and 2(f), respectively. We emphasize here that
0.005 σ
y
is equivalent to 6.7 MPa or an applied force of ca. 10 N, demonstrating that extensive stress-induced microplastic activity emerges at essentially the entirety of the macroscopically Hookean regime. This stands in strong contrast to crystalline metals, which do have a true elastic limit prior to reaching the anelastic and subsequently microplastic regime prior to yielding [43].

Despite the clear decrease in structural relaxation times relative to the zero-load case, the persistence of a waiting-time domain of fast dynamics is progressively reduced with increasing stress level and signs of dynamical arrest within the experimental time window emerge. Indeed, at
σ
A
=
0.8 σ
y
about 75 % of the TTCF conveys a static glassy solid with decorrelation timescales that approach those of the un-biased material. The observations deduced from Fig. 2 are further quantified by fitting pseudo one-time-correlation functions

, via the Siegert relation [44], and is directly related to the ISF. The resulting momentary time scales,

with error bars indicating the residual as derived from the Jacobian matrix based on least-squares curve fitting. Now, the application of a stress bias and its effect on the early waiting time regime becomes unambiguously clear: while the un-biased thermally-activated dynamics at zero stress is reflected by stationary dynamics at an average momentary relaxation time scale
τ 0
of about 20 000 s, a compressive stress of 0.005 of the yield stress significantly accelerates the structural dynamics, leading to up to a factor of 20 times faster relaxation times compared to zero stress. We explain this behavior by stress-facilitated transitions over low-energy barriers connected to the more frustrated substructure of the MG. Irrespective of
σ
A
, structural dynamics slows down as a function of
t w
, as low-energy barriers become increasingly exhausted. Therefore, the momentary relaxation time slows gradually down due to the diminished availability of accessible transitions and
τ
approaches
τ 0
, the level of un-biased thermally-activated dynamics at zero stress. However, the smaller the stress bias, the faster and more prolonged is the stress-induced accelerated dynamics within the temporal resolution of the in-situ XPCS experiments. This is in full accordance with computational approaches generating barrier height distributions that begin at effectively zero eV [45] and demonstrates not only admittance of thermally-activated stress-driven transport at virtually any stress, but also the quicker exhaustion of short decorrelation times with increasing applied stress. Thus, exploring the low-stress domain and a potential true microplastic limit, actually gives now rationale for the observation of long momentary relaxation times under high stress made in Ref. [34], underlining at the same time its core finding that time-aging time-superposition does not hold in the stress-driven transport regime.

While the decorrelation timescales exhibit a distinct evolution with
t w
, a steady behavior is observed for the shape parameter,
β
t w

[46] and assuming that the decorrelation time scales under stress approach the average decorrelation time scale under zero stress,

0.8 σ y
reveals simple exponential behavior. In other words, the shape parameter characterizing the evolution of decorrelation time scales,
β
, undergoes a gradual cross-over from compressed to simple exponential decorrelation upon the application of stress (Fig. 3(b). With the fact that
β
is known to transition from a stretched behavior in the undercooled liquid region, via simple exponential behavior near
T g
, to a compressed decorrelation in the glassy solid regime during cooling [39], we find thus that an applied stress induces the reverse
β
-evolution. This has to be seen as a short time-window averaging insight, and even though compressed decorrelation has been proposed to originate from ballistic-like atomic motion [47], we emphasize that recent work indicates that such compressed out-of-equilibrium dynamics may be a result of a small
t w
relative to the relaxation-time spectrum available to the glassy solid [48]. With increasing stress, e.g., stress-biased thermal activation, towards yielding of the material, the underlying relaxation-time spectrum broadens indeed systematically. This analogous trend to the temperature-dependent evolution during cooling gives strong indications for a dynamic correspondence between temperature-driven and stress-driven transport and reminds of the mechanically-driven glass transition [49] and a jamming-unjamming transition [9]. We note that this stress–temperature analogy is based on the shape parameter of the relaxation time distribution. Since the momentary relaxation times have not yet reached a stationary value at the final stages of each compression experiment, it remains an open question if and at which waiting time this analogy will be reflected by comparably shorter relaxation times in the higher stress domain.

Subsequently, we quantify the time-dependent slowing down of the accelerated dynamics induced by stress. The lower bound of the decorrelation time scale for the final segment of each TTCF can be defined as
ξ
lb
=
Δ t
TTCF
-
t
w
∗
where
Δ
t
TTCF
is the measurement’s duration and
t
w
∗
is the waiting time up to which the decorrelation window was sufficiently wide to allow for reliable fitting to the stretched exponential function. Based on this,
ξ
lb
thus reflects the least amount of time that might be needed for the structure to decorrelate at the according waiting time. Values of
ξ
lb
are plotted in Fig. 3(a) as anchor symbols and amount to ca. 8000–12000 s, while the lower bound of
τ
observed under zero stress corresponds to ca. 17000 s. Consequently,
ξ
lb
approaches
τ 0
over a time period that depends on the stress level, which indicates an exhaustion of accessible timescales for a given stress bias. After sufficiently long waiting times, the dynamical time scales under stress are therefore expected to attain similar levels to the initial unstressed condition.

Removing the stress bias, as schematically indicated in Fig. 1 (stage C) leads to dynamical arrest for the time of observation. As shown in Fig. 4(a) after
σ
A
= 0.02 σ
y
, where the first 350 s of low contrast represent the active unloading to the low-load limit of the load frame at
0.005 σ
y
, a dynamically inactive state is observed for a duration of 15 000 s. We note that this unloading stress level (
σ
A
in Fig. 1) resulted in the shortest decorrelation times upon loading (Fig. 2(b), Fig. 3(a). After waiting for
Δ
t
w
=
80 h (ca. 144 times the relaxation time of the zero-stress case) without speckle pattern acquisition, resumed XPCS-probing reveals re-activation of structural dynamics within the experimental time window (Fig. 4(b), corresponding to stage D in Fig. 1). This shows how the stress-driven glass structure initially must be dominated by much larger relaxation times than accessible by the experiment. In other words, the material was dynamically stuck in a low energy minimum, a state which − despite the long time scale connected to it − is of transient nature because the structure eventually evolves and relaxation times again become traceable. Only aging of the stress-induced state eventually admits sufficiently short relaxation times such that atomic-scale dynamics again can be probed. This observation is in line with recent rejuvenation experiments, in which an increased excess enthalpy is observed for an extended amount of time [20,50], but which decays noticeable after ∼ 105 s – a time scale very compatible with 80 h. In this light, rejuvenation would be the consequence of the microplasticity admitted by the frustrated part of the glass. Irrespective of this interpretation, we find that stress-driven transport and therefore structural changes eliminate immediate access to short relaxation times, implying transient but deep minima in an energy landscape picture and a certain lag-time before observable recovery dynamics sets in.

In summary, we pursued XPCS experiments on bulk MGs under compressive stress to test a partitioned microstructural view of MGs, in which elastically stiff and microplastically active structural components play distinctly different roles. As a result, we identified three dynamically different regimes, which are 1) stationary dynamics under zero-load, 2) stress-induced accelerated dynamics at early waiting times followed by a gradual, stress-dependent aging response towards zero-load relaxation time scales under load, and 3) dynamical arrest immediately after un-loading while structural activity is re-established at long waiting times under zero-load conditions. The stress-induced transport reveals a transition of the time-scale evolution from a compressed to an exponential form suggesting a strong similarity of transport changes induced by stress and temperature [39]. Most astounding, however, is the strongly accelerated microplastic transport at even the lowest applied stresses.

These observations promote a microstructural picture of a MG, in which more frustrated domains account for the here discovered atomic-scale transport at very small loads. Mapped onto thermally-activated plasticity, the applied stress-bias has been shown to broaden (not shift) the barrier energy distribution of model glasses [51], and the here presented results demonstrate how this broadening allows the transport-admitting part of the structure to undergo structural rearrangements until exhausted. Related to this stress-induced microplastic flow is a recent theoretical prediction for MGs that presents a picture of the underlying potential energy landscape with barriers in the meV range in a highly unrelaxed model glass [52]. Being therefore of different origin and in a time-scale regime than probed here experimentally, it highlights how a certain fraction of a glassy solid may microplastically flow either by a high degree of frustration or by a surprisingly low stress in the long-time and stress-biased thermally-activated domain as covered here.

In contrast to this stands the reproducible elastic-to-plastic transition in the GPa-stress-regime, which must be controlled by a stiff and system-spanning network of low-energy motifs, as seen to develop during fore-front microsecond isothermal annealing in model glass simulations (Fig. 4d). This microstructural picture entails that MGs have no true elastic limit, as defined for crystalline alloys, but that structural changes can be imparted at unexpectedly low mechanical stresses. However, any such structural change inflicted below the yield-transition is expected to be recoverable, as the stable and stiff elastic network will exert a back stress onto the frustrated domains [26]. Enthalpy changes or assumed viscoplastic strains due to elastic loading must therefore be transient, for which the here conducted in-situ XPCS loading experiments now give a microstructural rationale. Indeed, the well-known effects of shape-memory [53,54], recoverable enthalpy relaxation [50], and negative creep [55] are all concluded to be a direct manifestation of the here proposed microstructural picture for which the presented in-situ XPCS measurements provide the first direct experimental evidence for ample low-barrier transport.
